953DD848F83541919030256910CE454C.description: Examine the impact of faith-motivated service and communal endeavors on individuals and communities.

B527760FE6C94ACDA71AB190AC2893E5.description: Explain how the planned Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat might affect one's life, faith development and call to evangelize.

62E361F08919452D859D90A56CB7B52F.description: Create, in collaboration with one's peers and teacher, a plan for participation in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat.

28DDC1C38C1E4B9EBD06C153A787324E.description: Describe how one's experience in a Christian Action Project, rally and/or retreat affects one's life and understanding of the call to evangelize.

02C989351C504BFD85D539F5EA45F100.description: Describe the relationships between interfaith dialogue and Pope Francis' concepts of: building a 'culture of encounter' (e.g., Evangelii Gaudium - The Joy of the Gospel 'care of our common home' (e.g., Laudato Si' â€“ Praise be to You).

5B9E6FC6768346A688959A741B65EE8D.description: Research case studies where interfaith dialogue results in positive change among Jews, Christians and/or Muslims (e.g., Albania's Muslim and Christian populations, Pope Paul VI's Nostra Aetate, the work of Saskatchewan born Sister Rosaleen Zdunich B.Ed. M.Sc. ).

DF556D8A4C8740E68FF74B2336B184F6.description: Investigate how interfaith dialogue is supported by understanding historic events and movements such as: genocidal acts (e.g., the Holocaust, Holodomor, the Kurdish Genocide: Al-Anfal Campaign), the Crusades, religious extremism within Judaism (e.g., the Kingdom of Israel/Tzrifin Underground), religious extremism within Christianity (e.g., Ku Klux Klan), religious extremism within Islam (e.g., Al-Qaeda).

1CD1DFC5835A44FC8EAABBCC07DE88AE.description: Describe the effects of persecution on interfaith dialogue throughout history faced by Jews (e.g., anti-Semitism), Christians (e.g., martyrdom) and Muslims (e.g., Islamophobia).

AACE9C6169A14F4BAAD3CD048CB00D31.description: Compare rituals of worship, forms of prayer, development of moral codes, and religious artistic expression of Jews, Christians and Muslims.

0C18CF68D9D544A9B69EAC3E387B27F2.description: Discuss Jewish, Christian and Muslim views on the role of key religious historical figures such as Abraham, Isaac, Ishmael, Noah, Moses, Mary, Jesus and Mohammed.

99452FE3C689414A84AE4CE5DC550033.description: Examine key principles of interfaith dialogue such as commitment to: accept others as equal partners, learn and share rather than teach, respect diversity within and among religions, include all religious and spiritual communities who wish to be engaged in dialogue, seek to understand what is true and holy in other religions (e.g., Nostra Aetate), challenge the misuse of religion for political gain or to justify violence or coercion, critique one's own tradition and seek to understand criticisms of that tradition, critically appraise online materials and conversations about diverse religious and spiritual traditions, collaborate on common goals (e.g., peace, environment, poverty, human dignity).

C3ADF6888CF24800B5400B4A52DE7DEA.description: Examine principles, benefits and challenges of interfaith dialogue.

155FA80EA442407399BD7064C63908B0.description: Examine perspectives on life after death and spiritual beings by responding to arts expressions such as: Traditional Powwow dances, On Eagle's Wings by Michael Joncas (Psalm 91 and Isaiah 40:31), The First Nation Art Garden (Toronto Zoo's Turtle Island Conservation Program), the murals of Berthold Imhoff in St. Peter's Cathedral at Muenster, Saskatchewan., The Ecstasy of St. Teresa of Avila sculpture by Bernini, The Fall of the Rebel Angels painting by Pieter Bruegel, The Ladder of Divine Ascent, St. John Climacus, excerpts from Dante's Inferno or John Milton's Paradise Lost, other contemporary works (e.g., music, literature, cartoons, visual art, film).

74B40CD5BF624938ADBA6EF56422EF29.description: Contrast Catholic teachings (CCC 1673, 1237, 2116, 2117) about exorcism and acts of divination (e.g., sÃ©ance, Ouija boards, astrology, palm reading) with pop culture views (e.g., dismissive harmless games, portrayals in horror films).

4E21DCE882564C0D81C2B9FFC75C0E4D.description: Assess how one's exposure to varying spiritual and religious viewpoints influence personal beliefs about life, death and spiritual beings considering concepts such as: personal ethics and morality, sin and forgiveness, obedience and freedom, hope.

7EE0D80B9CF1422392578B29206A8BAC.description: Examine the role of saints in Catholic tradition and contrast this to other approaches to prayer related to the deceased including traditional First Nations' ceremonies and others (e.g., Catholic prayer with and through the saints, Catholic prayer for and through the dearly departed, Eastern Christian concept of eternal memory, the Hindu cycle of rebirth).

1938F7D93F034A688B8A97A7DD5DBFD9.description: Investigate concepts of life after death from various spiritual and religious viewpoints considering perspectives such as: Christian views about heaven, hell and purgatory, Byzantine and Orthodox, understandings of the journey of theosis, First Nations, MÃ©tis and Inuit traditions, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism traditions, Atheism.

224B6890229B4BB3B54489B311DD8D0E.description: Pose questions for inquiry regarding the spiritual nature of one's existence through the use of examples such as: creation stories and myths, beliefs about the Creator, the eternal nature of spirit or soul, Elders' knowledge of vision quests and spiritual ways of knowing, spiritual beings such as angels, demons, animal spirits, ghosts, spiritual apparitions and supernatural experiences.

C5FAA15CA7744D50B807407128091AD0.description: Discuss the relationship between scientific inquiry and spiritual and religious beliefs (e.g., physical evidence for spiritual claims).

B49F57F4C38C4D72BF33E838740F7289.description: Express personal beliefs about life after death and spiritual beings considering Catholic perspectives and other views.

6E2A89727933471BA46F6CC77EEF669D.description: Construct a plan for personal prayer and action using Jesus as a model (e.g., prayed in solitude, led others in prayer, fasted).

2D404B5D60BF440D95E3046E5B232C5A.description: Explain the Catholic view that prayer should be affective in nature (e.g., causing personal change or growth) and thereby leads to acts of goodness (e.g., being an instrument of God's will, deepening one's connection to God).

AEAE39533E3A4675A73B503DFEC0DA79.description: Examine the infusion of cultural traditions within Catholic ecclesial prayer rituals including First Nations traditions (e.g., smudging ceremonies within the Catholic church, Way of The Cross events incorporating cultural art works, Theophany Water Blessing, diverse Holy Week cultural traditions such as Catholic Filipino and Ukrainian Catholic).

CAA3542860C24FDAA258EBC8BE27FAF5.description: Investigate similarities and differences in prayer among Christian, Jewish, First Nations and MÃ©tis traditions (e.g., mealtime prayers, prayers of thanksgiving, praise and worship, petition and intercession).

5D6B4641446541AD97C92763441CF421.description: Create an arts expression in response to the five types of prayer listed within the Catechism of the Catholic Church including: petition (e.g., asking for what one wants), intercession (e.g., prayer for others) thanksgiving (e.g., gratitude for gifts of life and love, moving away from selfishness, enjoying what life brings), praise and worship (e.g., respect for God, celebrates everything coming from and belonging to God, results in bringing God's love to others), blessing and adoration (e.g., recognition of the nature of God, leads to being 'poor in spirit', recognizes everything comes from and belongs to God and therefor everything can be used for the glory of God).

E7D3D87AAAD04227BD14A3C25003A16B.description: Discuss relationships among and benefits of: personal prayer (i.e., prayers dealing with personal issues), private prayer (i.e., prayers made by oneself), communal prayer (i.e., praying with others).

78A51B62E8884C03A1B538D445DBBC13.description: Analyze and discuss how one's prayer life may be influenced by Catholic teachings regarding: why pray, how to pray, what to pray for, when to pray, to whom a person should direct prayer (e.g., God the Father, God the Son, God the Holy Spirit), through and with whom a person may be encouraged to pray (e.g., Mary, saints, the angelic host).

8CB014E6351C402E9A7B593C069A72F3.description: Analyze Catholic prayer teachings and reflect on their influence on one's prayer life.

2B3AC25F710049F09355494055A7BE19.description: Apply to societal issues such as sanctity of life, marginalization and social sin the five steps of effective social action identified by the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops: Be present to the poor., Develop understanding of the causes of suffering., Judge the situation in light of Gospel values and Church teaching., Think and act creatively, guided by the vision of the kingdom of God., Act together (in solidarity) to transform unjust situations.

0CFB52D2A3BF4C578E298094DC8D11C6.description: Discuss the marginalization of First Nations, MÃ©tis and Inuit peoples of Canada through topics such as: the Truth and Reconciliation process and Calls to Action, Jordan's Principle (e.g., First Nations and MÃ©tis children disadvantaged due to conflicts involving federal and provincial bureaucracy) treaties that remain unfulfilled.

D1EB7775EF8A4BC18B3D911447492EE8.description: Analyze and discuss how a person's views might be challenged when presented with Church teaching regarding the 'Preferential Option for the Poor' supported in Scripture and Tradition such as: Ex. 22:20-26, Is. 58: 5-7, Mt. 25:34-40, Lk. 4:16-21, Pope Paul VI's encyclical Populorum Progressio #23, Pope John Paul II's encyclical Centesimus Annus #58.

F1AC93F6698148E89880585BB3BA34F8.description: Examine the cause and effects of various poverties (e.g., economic, relational, spiritual) in the world and how the Catholic community seeks to address them.

C25161C63A3D4136B3F5147098983528.description: Explain how Scripture and Church teachings influence personal views on: life issues (e.g., abortion, euthanasia, palliative care, Dr. assisted-suicide, suicide, capital punishment), the treatment of the marginalized (e.g., the poor, elderly, disabled, those suffering from discrimination, human trafficking) and social sin within contemporary society (e.g., pornography, prostitution, gambling).

57CEB06A2AB84279977B83FB2728FCCE.description: Use the experiences of Mary to deepen understanding of Catholic social teachings regarding issues such as: reverence for life (e.g., "yes" to the angel Gabriel, mourning of Jesus), treatment of the marginalized (e.g., Mary as widow, as refugee, as homeless, as poor) and social sin (e.g., Mary living in a male-dominated society).

2905EF92998242C98A5B8D9CAA19E2C7.description: Use scripture to support understanding and application of Catholic social teachings on reverence for life, treatment of the marginalized and social sin.

3A504D4AC76D4686AFAD5D33D18C0B0F.description: Contrast Catholic teachings on reverence for life, treatment of the marginalized and social sin with moral relativist examples.

E9B06F17FDE8478B99AFC5A07157EA43.description: Discuss effects, culpability and individual responsibility resulting from: original sin (i.e., Adam and Eve), personal sin (i.e., actual sin), social sin (i.e., structures of sin).

C8B6759BF4D84430BE26A95B4A7AD9D6.description: Examine Catholic social teachings and actions involving: reverence for life, treatment of the marginalized, social sin.

9AF079B1D0114410A32A09C0E9ECB039.description: Examine how a Christian life may lead to supporting the work of Canadian social movements and organizations (e.g., Chalice, Christian Near East Welfare Association, Development and Peace, World Wildlife Fund Canada, MÃ©tis Nation - Saskatchewan).

582CD1BF81D048EAB4B049A51D933A6A.description: Construct meaning for the expression 'politically active', and inquire into how living according to the Gospel is a political act (e.g., called to transform culture).

32FECD1CCF3A4E73868226825185C0FD.description: Examine the obligation of a Catholic to assist those who are politically marginalized by governmental policies including First Nations and MÃ©tis peoples and others (e.g., veterans, refugees).

0D9C051AC410412EA574C6A395C1F754.description: Discuss benefits and challenges of the six responsibilities of citizens to the country identified by the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops, 2001 including: obey civil authority, vote, participate in public life pay taxes, welcome immigrants and refugees, defend the country.

A65BA71907EC4696BBB6B4FC41C17977.description: Discuss benefits and challenges of the ten responsibilities of a good government identified by the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops, 2001 including: respect the dignity of the person, accept the rule of law, promote the common good and good order, protect the family, safeguard the right to life of every person, be responsible for the economy and well-being of citizens, give access to work and just wages, ensure religious freedom, look after the health of citizens, defend the country.

8C98BF9FE7BE48B6860DAE6E437FD30C.description: Examine Christian perspectives on political themes such as globalization, economic inequality and self-interest.

13339ECC20C94B569A4EC92065F56589.description: Debate issues of the primacy of conscience versus the authority of church and government (e.g., misuse of power, civil disobedience, conscientious objection, other issues addressed in the Pastoral Letter on Freedom of Conscience and Religion, April, 2012 - CCCB).

F9FFE30AA02947D8ABA50477B1EA98E4.description: Contrast Peter's words: "we must obey God rather than any human authority" (Acts 5:29) with Paul's writings on submitting to governing authority (e.g., Romans 13: 1-7).

14780650F58D405DB2FD0B096554A3D9.description: Explain Jesus' statement to "Give back to Caesar what is Caesar's and to God what is God's" (Mk. 12:17).

BCF5A7AD2F544C76883EC9CF0EDE5AB1.description: Examine the benefits, challenges and responsibilities of being both a member of a church and an engaged citizen.

5EA387523CCA430489FCE7E8A9930434.description: Analyze what is meant by the 'new evangelization' of the Catholic Church and propose methods to achieve it.

C086E0BECBEC48FCA3DECC16375FCC35.description: Demonstrate connections among: the call to evangelization in contemporary society, the Scriptural question: 'Am I my brother's keeper?' and Pope Francis' concepts of a "culture of encounter" (e.g., Evangelii Gaudium 3) and "missionary disciples" (e.g., Evangelii Gaudium 120).

D52A5B0C1C204B04B10E925865BEE8E3.description: Role play the evangelization of those who oppose Christianity (e.g., atheistic scientist, agnostic, secular humanist or moral relativist).

92CD9D6BCC4D4F77A822B6028EAFABD2.description: Investigate how proselytization may lead to societal challenges such as assimilation practices or religious extremism.

C0141FF8364C4C0781483C65B0C5172B.description: Investigate how individual Catholics, although flawed, have led others into a relationship with God through their example (e.g., Catholics in the community and well known individuals such as Pope John Paul II, Saint Mother Teresa, Jean Vanier, Saint Kateri Tekakwitha, Chiara Lubich, Catherine Doherty, Father Athol Murray).

FEBA0ACE59E94B2F8D3D27BEB813B9EF.description: Examine how effective evangelization incorporates the Canadian Conference of Catholic Bishops' five important actions of the Catholic Church in pursuit of her mission: Proclaim Jesus Christ, Worship Christ through the sacraments, Form a communion of people, Give witness, and Serve.

119D7B6C939943B5889F38DB5BAA8EE4.description: Distinguish between examples of evangelization (e.g., involving zeal, respect for freedom) and proselytization (e.g., involving coercive indoctrination, unjust use of force and power).

ACB5843E66564AE6AE2E996E7895D3EC.description: Explain how the call to evangelize is both individual and communal in nature.

5E8E916783214FB0A4D2111AA638BD6F.description: Investigate Catholic evangelization as a call from God.

A999B651BCD048B886E8E275352D546B.description: Assess arguments naming Jesus as the Messiah from Catholic teaching authorities such as: the magisterium (e.g., John Paul II's Redemptoris Missio #5 and Dives In Misericordia #3), saints (e.g., St. Augustine, St. Teresa of Avila), theologians (e.g., Joseph Ratzinger/Pope Benedict XVI, Dr. Josephine Lombardi), apologists (e.g., C.S. Lewis, Peter Kreeft).

58018F78BA254E6CAF7135BD9F7B619F.description: Outline beliefs and discuss motives of those who do not view Jesus as Messiah including followers of the new atheism, Jews and Muslims.

7AEA1D6EA1C74F199C79998E9DF666C6.description: Analyze how the miracles of Jesus in Scripture support a claim of Jesus as Messiah including miracles such as: curing the sick, casting out demons, controlling nature, raising the dead.

84E491EA99BC446FA090CF48ACC1FE13.description: Analyze how events from Scripture support the conviction of Jesus as Messiah such as: the Incarnation (e.g., the Word became flesh, Jn. 1: 1-14), infancy narratives of Jesus including the role of Mary, baptism of Jesus, temptation of Jesus, statements made by Jesus indicating his messianic nature such as Mt. 12: 6 and Luke 4: 16-21, Transfiguration of Jesus, Institution of the Eucharist at the Last Supper, Agony in the Garden, death and Resurrection.

8ACD4DCC27064D86A93B4E1C7B441AD3.description: Provide examples of how God spoke to people prior to and following the Word becoming flesh and living among humanity in Jesus.

6718F17D0D734F47A6F0E3D7D6DD025C.description: Examine the implications of naming John the Baptist as the last prophet and the prophet of the Most High.

460C00CA3A43407D9F44FB76C8B5906A.description: Discuss the concept of Messiah as developed within Jewish history and prophesized within the Old Testament.

5B16D31D6A0744008F3F99830E9AB0A9.description: Evaluate the essential Christian conviction of Jesus as the Messiah.

357581937EC648BB96B0D056643D37EC.description: Discuss various motives of fraudulent claims of miracles (e.g., power, money, fame, religious zealotry/fanaticism).

ADA39688A18744ABBF839C3B9435DDF6.description: Investigate the Church's approach to claims of miracles including: canonization of saints (e.g., venerable to blessed to saint), validation processes (e.g., use of research and science), examination for purpose (e.g., a discernable message from God), authentication of a miracle, deeming it worthy of belief but not a requisite of faith.

AA21D697EE54441982B024BA2B40146F.description: Explain the Catholic understanding of the source, purpose and validity of various miracles such as those involving: Moses (e.g., burning bush, plagues, parting of the Red Sea), Jesus (e.g., water to wine, healing, commanding weather, casting out demons, raising the dead), Pentecost (e.g., the miracle of the tongues). Church authenticated miracles in modern history (e.g., Fatima, Lourdes, St. Padre Pio, Our Lady of Guadalupe and the tilma of St. Juan Diego).

54ED3E48EFEE491D8295282631CCF4D0.description: Compare secular and religious perspectives on miracles including the Catholic emphasis on a miracle's source and purpose (e.g., message or resulting teaching).

03F1CD8927C2483EB5B48B33637E6344.description: Recognize the value of wonder and awe in relation to the beauty of miracles of life, Creation, and all works of an omnipotent God.

F3161C71509C4060AC3291F6FB942ED6.description: Investigate the existence, source, and purpose of miracles through examples from: the Old Testament, the New Testament, the historical era of the past 200 years.

B0D360B4D3EC46108FDE3336582287BE.description: Examine how individuals, although flawed, can exemplify characteristics of:  forgiveness lived (e.g., ImmaculÃ©e Ilibagiza, Rev. Dale Lang), mercy lived (e.g., Sister Helen Prejean, Oskar Schindler), generosity lived (e.g., St. Vincent de Paul, St. Marguerite d'Youville), justice lived (e.g., Malala Yousafzai, Ovide William Mercredi of the Cree Nation, Aung San Suu Kyi, Gabriel Dumont of the MÃ©tis Nation), joy lived (e.g., St. AndrÃ© Bessette, St. ThÃ©rÃ¨se of Lisieux , St. Philip Neri).

B8F2DFE50FF84F44A3ACDD39F71CD1EF.description: Express how humility can lead to: joy, generosity, a Magnificat moment (i.e., modest recognition of one's talents as gifts from the Creator), social justice.

2A096AEED7564E40B423962E56B75F6D.description: Discuss ways that sacramental reconciliation involves forgiveness, mercy, generosity, justice and joy.

E0D446CCD1B4474D90C8AE4386CBF5A0.description: Recognize conversion as a process involving contrition, confession and correction.

B8DC7AE665C547CA841905CE57FD160D.description: Investigate why and how one should forgive or seek forgiveness when forgiveness is difficult in situations such as: genocide and terrorism (e.g., Holocaust, Holodomor, Rwanda, recent terrorist acts such as 9/11), racial segregation including First Nations residential school experiences and others (e.g., Apartheid and slavery), abuse and violence (e.g., sexual, emotional, domestic), bullying (e.g., cyber, physical, emotional, mental, spiritual), betrayal by a friend or family member.

B612B61104CC48E49F58065A98F02576.description: Create a representation (e.g., visual, written, digital) incorporating distinguishing features of forgiveness from a Catholic perspective such as: forgiveness does not excuse an act forgiveness does not remove responsibility of the offender to repair damage done by an act, forgiveness desires positive change, not revenge, forgiveness does not have limitations.

D1182D94A7C94349BE405C3CD8D990DD.description: Respond to Christian religious artworks and writings pertaining to forgiveness, mercy, generosity, justice and joy such as: Rembrandt's The Prodigal Son, Michaelangelo's The Creation of Adam, various Byzantine icons such as Christ the Pantocrator or The Mother of Perpetual Help, local church art such as stained glass and statues, excerpts from Pope Francis's Joy of the Gospel, The Jesus Prayer (i.e. Lord Jesus Christ, Son of God, have mercy on me, a sinner), Gospel parables such as The Prodigal Son, The Good Samaritan, The Workers in the Vineyard various poems in honour of Saint Mother Teresa

7FEB0C070F954DBEA2CCE74B183F9DA7.description: Examine Catholic connections between: original sin and forgiveness, mercy, generosity, justice and joy, personal sin and forgiveness, mercy, generosity, justice and joy.

016F53F6076E4D43B915A8E887C634FE.description: Express Catholic perspectives on forgiveness, mercy, generosity, justice and joy within the ongoing nature of salvation history.

D590658D2DC24EE79316E6BD00A7C229.description: Discuss examples of diminished responsibility for immoral acts (e.g., conditions for mortal sin).

654438F561844D40AFDF3C040215D26C.description: Collaborate with peers to represent the Catholic teaching that a good intention can never justify an evil act.

9ABDADAF780F47528CFDC50BCFDB60AB.description: Discuss legalistic and relational considerations in making a moral judgement including: the moral object (i.e., action), the moral intention (i.e., motive), the moral circumstance (i.e., context and consequence).

04D2E9BB8FD84AB785E6F297A0D94E56.description: Distinguish the difference between merely avoiding evil and doing good using examples from Mosaic law and relational perspectives (e.g., the parable of the Good Samaritan).

57E15782FCB34C6FAE850A87B59415D8.description: Contrast how each of the Ten Commandments was understood from a legal perspective and a contemporary relational context through discussions such as: keep holy the Sabbath (e.g., adherence to Sabbath laws moving towards relationship building with God), honour mother and father (e.g., moving from honouring parents towards honouring parents and other elders within the community), do not commit adultery (e.g., rules and punishment pertaining to extra-marital sex moving towards personal responsibility for sexual morality), do not covet (e.g., person as possession moving towards recognition of the dignity of the person).

E1957A42B7D642A5B5CC75739803E06B.description: Discuss the shift in understanding the Ten Commandments as laws (e.g., enforced by scribes and Pharisees) to a relationship with God in the spirit of the law (e.g., Jesus as fulfillment of the law).

A8CCA60985E8436FB1B618F91201A716.description: Discuss the place of the Ten Commandments within Mosaic Law.

CEC15D3CFB0D49AD9A894C8D54C39609.description: Contrast the Mosaic Law perspective on morality and sin with a contemporary Christian perspective of relationship building with God.

528B7B190669460FBFBA98C6EE4E6D8F.description: Explain key uses of the Gospels after they were written (e.g., prayer, liturgy, catechesis, evangelization) and examine their influence on communal and personal faith development.

FF5E5D2692394F91A31EE3894FF1A321.description: Discuss how understanding Gospel formation and intent influences the development of faith using examples such as: the development of the synoptic gospels, the theory of a potential Q-source, presence of unique content within John's Gospel, conflicting interpretations of scripture (e.g., contextualists vs. Bible literalists).

96DBD8A9A62E45798EA6B298513D79C0.description: Identify the target audiences of all four Gospels and discuss implications for the writing style, content, and sequencing of the Good News according to each of the four evangelists (i.e., Matthew, Mark, Luke and John).

4F8134A7BED4437583396A5987C573EB.description: Discuss the impact on personal faith of skepticism concerning the historical accuracy of the Gospels (e.g., accuracy of oral traditions, limited historical documents on the life and teaching of Jesus).

C7C195B042CC4F7EB38AC8360CECF31F.description: Discuss the influence of oral teachings (i.e., stage two of Gospel formation) on the written Gospels (i.e., stage three of Gospel formation).

E8F4003C08B8408080A82E50350AF1AB.description: Explain why the Gospels were not written immediately following the death and resurrection of Jesus (e.g., expectation of impending Second Coming, prevalence of oral tradition, literacy rates, etc.).

B40FC648118A4298AC3D15D765385498.description: Outline and explain the three stages of Gospel formation including: life and teaching of Jesus Christ, oral tradition, written Gospels.

05D2366CF35A49A08F875FD09C00EB4A.description: Examine the history of the development of the four Gospels and consider implications for faith formation.

F59AAE7C714342E79338698016097688.description: Discuss various ways the prophets describe the Eucharistic covenant of the Messiah such as: new covenant (e.g., Jeremiah), everlasting covenant (e.g., Isaiah), covenant of peace (e.g., Ezekiel).

BEB373414C9B49FEBA361340841C3403.description: Represent how the prophets play the role of bridge from Moses to Messiah within salvation history.

693A77B89831464C81DAA33947AE35C0.description: Examine connections between David and the Messiah as presented through various prophets (e.g., Samuel, Isaiah, Jeremiah).

3CE676C88BE54D6DBBC16F8A5657553C.description: Identify how David fulfills the roles of priest, prophet and king, and discuss one's own call to such roles within the covenant.

F2A219A192FB4BB3BA8592EF7466A2C3.description: Examine Catholic perspectives on the Davidic covenant such as: David's rise to and loss of power (e.g., trust in God), the role of Jerusalem in salvation history (e.g., capital city uniting the northern and southern tribes of Israel), the importance of the Temple in salvation history (e.g., physical reminder of the covenants with Adam, Noah, Abraham, Moses and David giving added significance to Mt. 12:6).

B6853F328E924F048A826C87C089319E.description: Identify ways the story of Moses foreshadows the story of Jesus including Passover for the Paschal mystery.

82075C567C114F4499D3901789068F0A.description: Explain the significance of the name of God revealed to Moses (i.e., "I am"), and collaborate to examine the significance of other key faith experiences of Moses.

EFD5C8097A484D1699E919FA51EED9FD.description: Give examples of how individuals within the Catholic community, including oneself, respond to the revelation of God's commitment through covenant.

97A4E16AC3D140F496C90A8921F664C3.description: Interpret lessons learned about hearing and heeding the call of God through the stories of: Moses (e.g., God commissions us to do His work), David (e.g., the smallest or seemingly least can be great with God) prophets of the Old Testament (e.g., Miriam â€“ courageously live and celebrate your faith in God, Jonah - you cannot run from the call of God, Samuel - sometimes we need others to help us discern God is calling us).

1722E753E89D44E28450A26531947F42.description: Examine the significance of God's covenantal relationship with humanity through the stories of: Moses, David, selected prophets of the Old Testament.
